awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Rapidly Deployable Mobile Sensor Robots for Disaster Response and Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to commercialize previous research in tensegrity robots for new markets in disaster response. Future deaths and injuries of both victims and first responders during disaster rescues in unchartered, risky environments could be prevented by rapidly deploying sensor robots that use semi-autonomous technology to explore the regions of disasters, provide surveillance to inform first responders, and assist in the rescue of victims until human first responders can arrive. Current emergency response procedures are time-consuming, requiring first responders to don protective suits and hand place sensors to obtain air quality readings. Current disaster robots cannot be rapidly deployed and can be ineffective in navigating surface obstacles and climbing steep slopes to reach areas of interest. Instead, tensegrity sensor robots dropped from aerial vehicles, such as drones or helicopters, can land in dangerous, often difficult-to-reach areas and immediately transmit surveillance and environmental data. With this information, first responder teams can better understand the situational hazards and plan how best to ameliorate the emergency saving lives, while reducing costs and property damage. This proposed technology will also have broader impact in use for scientific and commercial monitoring and surveillance as well.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will advance the development of tensegrity robots, their durability, and their propulsion, de-risking the technology for the commercial market. This work will focus on expanding the features and structures of two robotic platforms: (1) stationary robots that provide persistent monitoring in one location and (2) mobile robots that are capable of ground travel over rough terrain (rubble, rocks, slopes).  Finite element analysis/computational fluid dynamics simulations will be used to reduce the robots' weight and improve impact-resilience and portability. Software improvements will focus on enhancing speed capabilities and energy efficiency for rough terrain locomotion. Control engineers will integrate robust Model Predictive Control to improve path planning and enhance the robots' locomotion in a wide range of topologies and environments. Improved software algorithms and user interfaces will provide first responders with summarized data analytics for real-time assessments in the field as well as deliver cloud-server support. Integrated playback functionality and data-driven learning will improve post-situation evaluations. With technologies that provide live 360-degree video feeds and greater incident intelligence, this project will improve rescue outcomes in future disaster recovery operations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Thousands of first responders have lost their lives saving others because they lacked a full understanding of the dangers at scenes of explosions, fires, and hazardous materials (HazMat) releases. Currently, sensors are hand carried into dangerous, potentially life-threatening environments to obtain proper situational awareness to keep first responders and the local community safe. Our rapidly deployable mobile sensor robots provides sensor data and visual information needed to make data-driven decisions and to safely plan the mitigation response, all from a safe distance away from the "hot zones."

The chief goal for the NSF SBIR Phase II was to move Squishy Robotics two sensor robots -the Stationary Robot for persistent monitoring in one location and the Mobile Robot capable of ground travel over rough terrain - toward commercialization, primarily in the disaster/HazMat response marketplace.

Squishy Robotics has succeeded in de-risking technologies used in the robots, in ruggedizing both versions of the robots, and in expanding capabilities and features so that the robots can better serve first responder customers. The robots are now capable of controlling optical gas imaging (OGI) cameras that can detect a wide ranges of gases. We have developed a pan-tilt mechanism to control both the horizontal and the vertical movement of the OGI and other camera and sensor payloads for use in detecting early wildfire and methane leaks.

Robust Model Predictive Control techniques were developed to increase robot speed and enable better path planning and movement even in unpredictable and uncharted environments for the mobile robot. New hardware and improved hardware designs have increased the Mobile Robot's ability to travel in terrains such as sand and uneven surfaces. The steering capabilities made possible by the Xbox controller and software improvements have increased the robot’s speed, maneuverability and state estimation. The benefits of the innovative parallel paired cable design developed in this grant is that only 2 paired cable actuators at a time perform as well or better than  fully actuated 24 non-paired cables, requiring 1/5th of the energy, lower weight, and fewer failure modes. A patent is pending on this innovation.

Squishy Robotics has built a pilot partnership community with industrial firms  and various top-tier fire departments that have helped refine and improve product features. In addition to their on-site testing and their suggestions for product improvements as these pilot partnerships progressed, Squishy Robotics has developed a group that, as early adopters and satisfied clients can serve as references to other first responder and corporate customers.

The increase in capabilities and features also expands the potential customer base to Oil and Gas companies, DoD/military stakeholders, and state and federal regulatory agencies.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2024
Modified by: Douglas D Hutchings

por.por_txt_cntn:
Thousands of first responders have lost their lives saving others because they lacked a full understanding of the dangers at scenes of explosions, fires, and hazardous materials (HazMat) releases. Our rapidly deployable mobile sensor robots provides sensor data and visual information needed to make data-driven decisions and to safely plan the mitigation response, all from a safe distance away from the "hot zones."
